results.title: Natural Glass
results.creator_credit: John King, Derek Wright and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Looks at a one-man revival of “natural” glass-making in New Zealand, contrasting the delicacies of glass making by one man with his normal job as a worker in a natural gas field.

results.title: Explosives: the two metre lifeline
results.creator_credit: David Plummer, Donald Crombie, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
In this 1974 film, the use of comedy and narrative drama are employed to demonstrate the correct handling of explosives and detonators. Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Mines Department, the film shows three people who handle explosives in the course of an ordinary day: a farmer removing tree stumps from his paddock, an opal miner in Coober Pedy and a ‘powder monkey’ on a road construction crew.

Introduced by a stereotypical ‘Aussie bloke’ drinking a beer at the pub, the film follows the three protagonists through their separate stories, as the narrator points out the mistakes and correct methods in their techniques. Demonstrating a casual, light-hearted approach to safety instruction, this film is a humorous presentation filled with expletives and colloquial terms, aimed to speak to workers on their level.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Exploration 1770, reviewed 1970
results.creator_credit: Tim Reid, Frank Bagnall, Stanley Dalby and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Contrasts Captain Cook’s observations on his voyage along the eastern coast of Australia in 1770 with scenes of the Royal Visit in 1970 and bicentenary celebrations including re-enactments of his landings. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tim Reid, Frank Bagnall, Stanley Dalby and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Encounter
results.creator_credit: Dept of Agriculture, Vic and Victoria. Ministry of Aboriginal Affairs
results.brief_description: Lake Tyers, which has been home to Aborigines for over one hundred years, was the site of a camp for aboriginal and non-aboriginal boys for ten days. Under the watchful eyes of voluntary skilled instructors the boys swam, sailed, canoed, scuba-dived, went hiking, fishing and played the residents at cricket. They made friends and learned teamwork and co-operation. Narrated by David Johnson.

results.title: Dream
results.creator_credit: Corinne Cantrill, Arthur Cantrill and Firebird Films
results.brief_description: A partly animated film based on a series of drypoint prints (‘Movements’ and ‘Combats’) by Australian printmaker Charles Lloyd on the theme of aggression in society. The sound composition by Arthur Cantrill is a mix of percussion and altered piano (plucking and hitting strings and soundboard, played by Arthur Cantrill), sound effects (including breathing), and electronically modified children’s laughter, recorded on a Nagra reel to reel tape recorder and transferred to 16mm magnetic tracks which were laid and mixed in a professional sound studio, where reverberation was added to some sections.

results.title: The Destruction of St. Patrick's College 1971
results.brief_description: The old St Patrick’s College was demolished to make way for an ecclesiastic office building. Professor Hartley Gratten, of the University of Texas considers, against the background of the demolition by Whelan the Wrecker, why Australians ignore their national heritage.
results.description: The old St Patrick’s College was demolished to make way for an ecclesiastic office building. Professor Hartley Gratten, of the University of Texas considers, against the background of the demolition by Whelan the Wrecker, why Australians ignore their national heritage.

results.title: The Daydreamer
results.brief_description: An example of independent Melbourne film production. A young man watching a girl pass by his window, imagines himself the hero in a series of fantastic situations in which the maiden’s honour is threatened by diverse evil characters. Made by Michael Martin, assisted by Garry Martin, Bruce McNaughton and Doug Hobbs.

results.title: A Bridge in music
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Alexander Shaw and Unesco
results.brief_description: Yehudi Menuhin and Eastern musician Ayana Deva Angadi compare Eastern and Western music and discuss how we can come to understand and appreciate that which is foreign to us in terms of that which is familiar. Characteristic techniques are shown, and the film includes examples of music from India, Japan, Cambodia, Italy, Germany and France.

results.title: Beard and bass
results.brief_description: An experimental short film about a bearded young man and a double bass. Clasping the instrument he tries to cross a street. Suddenly his attention is arrested by a girl whose charms he appreciates. She smiles at him and crosses the street. He stares at her and then realising suddenly that she has disappeared, he props up his double bass against the tree and disappears into the crowd. Music by George Dreyfus, edited by Peter Tammer.
